lead: This week in tech highlights significant developments in AI regulations, innovative product launches, and a notable shift in streaming services.

stories.title: New York is considering two bills to rein in the AI industry
stories.summary: New York's state legislature is set to consider bills aimed at regulating AI-generated content. The proposed NY FAIR News Act would require disclaimers on AI-generated news and mandate human editorial oversight. Additionally, the bills propose a three-year pause on new data center construction, reflecting growing bipartisan concerns over AI's impact.

stories.title: AT&T's budget-friendly phone for kids was designed with parental controls in mind
stories.summary: AT&T has launched the AmiGO Jr. Phone, a budget-friendly smartphone designed specifically for children. It features built-in parental controls, including live location tracking and screen time restrictions. This move positions AT&T as a key player in the market for kid-friendly devices, competing with existing products from other companies.

stories.title: Crypto.com places $70M bet on AI.com domain ahead of Super Bowl
stories.summary: In a bold move, Crypto.com has acquired the AI.com domain for a staggering $70 million, setting a new record for domain purchases. This acquisition highlights the growing importance and potential of AI in the tech landscape, especially as the Super Bowl approaches, where visibility could drive significant traffic.

stories.title: Apple's new iPads and MacBooks expected soon
stories.summary: Apple is reportedly preparing to unveil new iPads and MacBooks, including updates to the iPad Air and MacBook Pro models. The anticipated launch could introduce the new M5 Pro and M5 Max chips, alongside a low-cost MacBook aimed at emerging markets. This release is expected to enhance Apple's competitive edge in the tech market.

stories.title: Steam now lets developers display the exact date of when their game leaves Early Access
stories.summary: Steam has introduced a new feature allowing developers to specify the exact date their games will exit Early Access. This change aims to improve transparency for players and assist developers in managing expectations. The feature is optional, but it reflects Steam's commitment to enhancing the user experience within its platform.

stories.title: Anthropic buys Super Bowl ads to slap OpenAI for selling ads in ChatGPT
stories.summary: In a public spat, AI company Anthropic has purchased Super Bowl ads to criticize OpenAI for monetizing its ChatGPT platform through ads. This move highlights the competitive tensions within the AI industry as companies vie for ethical positioning and market share amidst growing scrutiny.

stories.title: YouTube Music starts putting lyrics behind a paywall
stories.summary: YouTube Music has begun limiting access to lyrics for free users, allowing only five songs per month before prompting a Premium subscription for full access. This change follows a testing phase and reflects a broader trend of streaming services monetizing additional features to boost subscription revenues.

stories.title: Countries Across Europe Take Action to Ban Social Media for Minors
stories.summary: At least 15 European countries are considering bans on social media for minors, inspired by Australia's regulatory actions. This movement underscores the increasing global concern over the impact of social media on youth and the push for safer online environments.

stories.title: The iPhone 17e will reportedly bring some key upgrades without raising the price
stories.summary: Apple's upcoming iPhone 17e is expected to retain its price while introducing significant upgrades, including the A19 chip and MagSafe charging. This strategy aims to appeal to budget-conscious consumers in emerging markets, reinforcing Apple's competitive stance against rivals like Google's Pixel.
